(Originally published in 2015.)

Every now and then something really amazing happens â€“ people with different perspectives on life will get beyond biases, prejudices, and stereotypes and have a real conversation with each other! I love when that happensâ€¦

Here are excerpts from a recent conversation about Christian Science on an Amazon Discussion Forum:

Mustaaaaard says:

Yeah. Christian Science. The people who let their children die because they donâ€™t believe in Tylenol. Eff off.

Karen says:

I was raised by a CS mom (now 87) and a non-religious dad (will be 97 in a month), and I could not have asked for better parents. My parents maybe didnâ€™t share the same religious beliefs, but they shared the same values and taught their children to take care of the environment, to appreciate the beauty of nature, to look for the good in people, to play fair, to not be quick to judge others, to not buy into every piece of hearsay, rumor, and gossip that comes our way, but to do our own research, and question our own beliefs and biases, and recognize the biases of others, too. Iâ€™m really grateful they are still in my life.

The Weasel asks:

Karen, can the core beliefs of CS be boiled down to a few bullet points? Can you try to list them as far as you understand them to be please?

Karen says:

Hi Weasel, Itâ€™s probably important to note that I am not an official spokesperson for the CS church or anything â€“ and I do not speak for any other CSists â€“ just for myself. CSists come in all shapes and sizes and colors and political parties and most professions (I even knew a CSist who was a dentist ğŸ™‚ ). Thereâ€™s no one in our church leadership telling us how to vote or who to vote for or where to stand on social-political issues â€“ that is left up to individual conscience. Some CSists are religious. Some are not. I am not. In my mind I make a distinction between the religion of Christian Science, and Christian Science as a way of living, and a way of looking at the world.

It might actually be easier to start with what CSists donâ€™t believe:

â€“ CSists donâ€™t believe in an anthropomorphic god

â€“ CSists donâ€™t believe the world was literally created in a week

â€“ CSists donâ€™t believe in literal places of hell and heaven

â€“ CSists donâ€™t believe in pleading, cajoling, and begging a capricious supernatural god who might choose to heal, or might choose to not heal his children

â€“ CSists donâ€™t believe in Original Sin, or that Godâ€™s children are sinners.

What CSists believe:

â€“ Mary Baker Eddy, the discover of CS, offers these synonyms for God: Principle, Mind, Soul, Spirit, Life, Truth, and Love.

â€“ CSists believe that Jesusâ€™ mission here was to show us how to heal. In the CS textbook, Eddy writes: â€œAtonement is the exemplification of manâ€™s unity with God, whereby man reflects divine Truth, Life, and Love. Jesus of Nazareth taught and demonstrated manâ€™s oneness with the Father, and for this we owe him endless homage. His mission was both individual and collective. He did lifeâ€™s work aright not only in justice to himself, but in mercy to mortals,- to show them how to do theirs, but not to do it for them nor to relieve them of a single responsibility.â€

What *I* have experienced: â€“ I have found that when Iâ€™m able to draw my thoughts close to Love â€“ to fill my thoughts up with joy, hope, and love (and eliminate fear, hate, and anger) â€“ I experience healing in my life. I donâ€™t have to plead with Love to heal me â€“ itâ€™s the nature of Love to heal. I donâ€™t consider these healings â€œmiraclesâ€ â€“ I consider them natural. I apologize. I realize this was kind of long. I couldnâ€™t figure out how to explain an entire way of life in a pithy post. Hope this helps you understand how at least ONE Christian Scientist looks at the world. And thanks for asking! ğŸ™‚

Karen

Lifelong Atheist says:

Christian Science parents who deliberately withhold medical care from their children in favor of prayer are potential murderers. If their child then dies, theyâ€™re actual murderers. Karen says:

Lifelong, I suppose there may be CSists who view medical science as The Enemy. I am not one of them. My brother-in-law is an anesthesiologist, my sister-in-law is an emergency room nurse, a niece is a medical doctor, a nephew just graduated from med school â€“ and these are all people I love and respect very much â€“ they are not my enemies â€“ they work very hard to do what they can to help their patients. But they are also all people of integrity and honesty â€“ and I donâ€™t doubt that theyâ€™d be the first to tell you that medical science is not perfect â€“ theories about cause and cure are constantly in flux; medications that help one person might kill another; what seems like â€œgood medical practiceâ€ today might prove to be the source of woe tomorrow. Iâ€™m sure weâ€™ve all had friends and family members for whom the medical treatment that was supposed to cure them actually ended up killing them â€“ I know I have. And Iâ€™m pretty sure weâ€™ve all seen those commercials on television that tell us about the side effects of drugs that might include liver problems, depression, vulnerability to infections, diarrhea, nausea, death, etc. â€“ Iâ€™m always wondering who is running out to get those medications, you know? I think a healthy skepticism in regards to medical science â€“ as well as Christian Science, faith healing, religious beliefs, mass media, and political propoganda â€“ is a good thing. Blind and unquestioning trust in any form of treatment does not seem very healthy to me.

Have you ever read Norman Cousinsâ€™s Anatomy of an Illness As Perceived by the Patient? I would highly recommend it. Hereâ€™s my review for it:

In the beginning of the book, Cousins tells us about the illness from which he was told by medical specialists he wouldnâ€™t be able to recover. He briefly describes how he declined to accept this medical verdict for himself, and with the support of his personal physician, set about putting into action a plan of treatment for himself which included plying himself with high doses of ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and humor (Candid Camera episodes, and Marx Brothers movies).Cousins was able to recover from his illness and later wrote a story about his treatment and recovery for the New England Journal of Medicine.

The remainder of the book shares communication from doctors and medical research that supports Cousinsâ€™s belief that medical care is both a science and an art â€“ and that positive human emotions play a big part in recovery from an illness. Cousins talks about the importance of a healthy doctor-patient partnership when treating disease, the part creativity and a â€œrobust will to liveâ€ plays in longevity, and the power found in placebos. Cousins writes: â€œIt is doubtful whether the placebo â€“ or any drug, for that matter â€“ would get very far without a patientâ€™s robust will to liveâ€¦ The placebo is only a tangible object made essential in an age that feels uncomfortable with intangiblesâ€¦ The placebo, then, is an emissary between the will to live and the body. But the emissary is expendable.â€

Cousins talks about the need so many seem to have to see their doctor DOing something, and giving them something tangible to help them. But Cousins suggests there may come a time when these â€œtangiblesâ€ are no longer needed.

Near the end of the book, Cousins asks the question: â€œIs there a conflict at times between the treatment of disease and the treatment of human beings?â€ What a great question! If a doctor treats his patient as just a lump of flesh to be prodded, injected, weighed, measured, and tested then, I think, a really important part of the healing process is missing. The best doctors, to my way of thinking, are the ones who are able to listen to their patients, reassure them, provide confidence in their healing, and value them as partners in the process. In my life I have encountered several practitioners with these fine qualities. After reading Cousinsâ€™s book, and the letters he included from doctors around the country, I am encouraged to believe that there is a growing number of medical physicians ready and willing to treat human beings, rather than just disease.

Thank you for asking this question. Christian Scientists have been lumped in with â€œfaith healersâ€ a couple times on this thread. Faith healers would not appreciate this â€“ Iâ€™m pretty sure they consider CS a cult and its members â€œun-Christianâ€ â€“ and CSists donâ€™t consider themselves faith healers. You wouldnâ€™t hear a CSist ever saying â€œItâ€™s Godâ€™s willâ€ that someone died, or â€œGod wanted that child with Him in heaven.â€ CSists donâ€™t do the talking in tongues thing, or the laying on of hands thing, or the handling serpents thing. CSists may be crazy, but they are a totally different kind of crazy. ğŸ™‚

Mary Baker Eddyâ€™s written a whole chapter on â€œPrayerâ€ in the CS textbook, Science and Health with Key to the Scriptures. Here are some thoughts about prayer from that chapter:

â€œGod is not moved by the breath of praise to do more than He has already done, nor can the infinite do less than bestow all good, since He is unchanging wisdom and Loveâ€¦ Prayer cannot change the Science of being, but it tends to bring us into harmony with itâ€¦ The mere habit of pleading with the divine Mind, as one pleads with a human being, perpetuates the belief in God as humanly circumscribed,- an error which impedes spiritual growth.

â€œGod is Love. Can we ask Him to be more? God is intelligence. Can we inform the infinite Mind of anything He does not already comprehend? Do we expect to change perfection? Shall we plead for more at the open fount, which is pouring forth more than we accept?â€¦ Are we really grateful for the good already received? â€¦The habitual struggle to be always good is unceasing prayerâ€¦

â€œâ€˜God is Love.â€™ More than this we cannot ask, higher we cannot look, farther we cannot goâ€¦ In divine Science, where prayers are mental, all may avail themselves of God as â€˜a very present help in trouble.â€™ Love is impartial and universal in its adaptation and bestowals.â€

What prayer feels like, for me, isâ€¦ itâ€™s like waking up to a beautiful sunrise in the morning or listening to an inspiring piece of music, or looking at the stars on a clear night â€“ itâ€™s a feeling of uplift â€“ of thoughts soaring, of fear dissipating, of a consciousness full of joy and good will. Often times my prayers come with humor â€“ laughing always seems to help get rid of fear for me â€“ and for me, fear is always a part of whatever problem Iâ€™m facing. And Love is always a part of the healing. Iâ€™ve sometimes known I was healed before I saw the healing manifested humanly â€“ I could feel the change in my thoughts.
